elements.content: The syntheses, crystal structures, and properties of C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3, C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3, and (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O are reported. These new creatinine zinc phosphites are built up from networks of vertex-sharing HPO3 pseudopyramids and various types of ZnO2N2, ZnO3N, and ZnO2N(H2O) tetrahedra, resulting in extended structures of different dimensionalities (as sheets, clusters, and chains, respectively). They demonstrate the structural effect of incorporating “terminal” (nonnetworking) Zn−N and Zn−OH2 moieties into zinc centers. Crystal data:  C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3, triclinic, P1̄ (No. 2), a = 8.9351(4) Å, b = 9.5011(4) Å, c = 9.9806(4) Å, α = 87.451(1)°, β = 85.686(1)°, γ = 89.551(1)°, Z = 4; C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3, monoclinic, P21/c (No. 14), a = 10.1198(7) Å, b = 7.2996(5) Å, c = 13.7421(9) Å, β = 107.522(1)°, Z = 4; (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O, triclinic, P1̄ (No. 2), a = 10.7289(6) Å, b = 10.9051(6)Å, c = 13.9881(8) Å, α = 89.508(1)°, β = 74.995(1)°, γ = 74.932(1)°, Z = 4.

elements.content: The creatinine zinc phosphites C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3 and (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O demonstrate new framework connectivity patterns in phosphite networks, as a neutral cluster and a single tetrahedral chain, respectively. By comparison, C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 adopts a known sheet topology based on fused tetrahedral 4- and 8-rings. The dimensionality of these structures can to some extent be correlated with the different ways in which the O, OH2, and N species are bonded to zinc.

By comparison, C4N3OH7⋅ZnHPO3 adopts a known sheet topology based on fused tetrahedral 4- and 8-rings. The dimensionality of these structures can to some extent be correlated with the different ways in which the O, OH2, and N species are bonded to zinc.

elements.content: Extended inorganic networks templated by organic cations now cover a remarkable range of compositions and structures. With inspiration from the example of aluminosilicate zeolites, the applications of some of these materials as catalysts, absorption agents, and ion exchangers have been investigated. Two areas of particular concern to synthetic and structural chemists are to devise rational and reliable syntheses for these materials and to understand the resulting, often-complicated, crystal structures. A starting point for the latter task is to classify the dimensionality of the inorganic network as zero- (clusterlike), one- (chainlike), two- (layered), or three-dimensional (continuous). Organically templated zinc phosphates (ZnPOs) demonstrate the existence of all four types of network. Examples from our own work (also showing that the use of the same template can lead to two or more completely different structures) include the anionic cluster compound N(CH3)4·Zn(H2PO4)3, which contains isolated 4 rings (4 tetrahedral units) with two pendant H2PO4 moieties attached to the zinc node. Slightly different preparation conditions led to the one-dimensional H3N(CH2)3NH3·Zn(HPO4)2 containing 4-ring ladders and H3N(CH2)3NH3·Zn2(HPO4)2(H2PO4)2 which incorporates 12-ring pores into its layered (two-dimensional) structure. Finally, N(CH3)4·Zn(HPO4)(H2PO4) possesses a novel three-dimensional framework built up from an all-12-ring topology. Numerous other ZnPOs showing great structural diversity have been prepared by many workers, but all of them can be assigned to a particular framework dimensionality.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Extended inorganic networks templated by organic cations now cover a remarkable range of compositions and structures. With inspiration from the example of aluminosilicate zeolites, the applications of some of these materials as catalysts, absorption agents, and ion exchangers have been investigated. Two areas of particular concern to synthetic and structural chemists are to devise rational and reliable syntheses for these materials and to understand the resulting, often-complicated, crystal structures. A starting point for the latter task is to classify the dimensionality of the inorganic network as zero- (clusterlike), one- (chainlike), two- (layered), or three-dimensional (continuous). Organically templated zinc phosphates (ZnPOs) demonstrate the existence of all four types of network. Examples from our own work (also showing that the use of the same template can lead to two or more completely different structures) include the anionic cluster compound N(CH3)4⋅Zn(H2PO4)3, which contains isolated 4 rings (4 tetrahedral units) with two pendant H2PO4 moieties attached to the zinc node. Slightly different preparation conditions led to the one-dimensional H3N(CH2)3NH3⋅Zn(HPO4)2 containing 4-ring ladders and H3N(CH2)3NH3⋅Zn2(HPO4)2(H2PO4)2 which incorporates 12-ring pores into its layered (two-dimensional) structure. Finally, N(CH3)4⋅Zn(HPO4)(H2PO4) possesses a novel three-dimensional framework built up from an all-12-ring topology. Numerous other ZnPOs showing great structural diversity have been prepared by many workers, but all of them can be assigned to a particular framework dimensionality.

elements.content: We are now studying organically templated zinc (hydrogen) phosphites containing (HPO3 2-) units. The pyramidal phosphite grouping can only make three P−O−Zn bonds; thus, its network structures are expected to be significantly different from those formed by tetrahedral phosphate groups. In fact, some of the resulting phases, such as H3N(CH2)3NH3·Zn(HPO3)2, are quite similar to corresponding zinc phosphates, whereas others, such as [H2N(CH2)2NH2]0.5·ZnHPO3, containing two separate, interpenetrating networks, akin to a coordination polymer, are novel. In this paper we describe our investigations into the creatinine (2-amino-3-methyl-1-imidazolin-5-one (I); Chart 1) zinc phosphite system and demonstrate how different degrees of ligation (Zn−N and Zn−OH2 bonds) at the zinc center can lead to different dimensionalities for the inorganic component of the structure, resulting in novel structure types.

In this paper we describe our investigations into the creatinine (2-amino-3-methyl-1-imidazolin-5-one (I); Chart 1) zinc phosphite system and demonstrate how different degrees of ligation (Zn-N and Zn-OH2 bonds) at the zinc center can lead to different dimensionalities for the inorganic component of the structure, resulting in novel structure types.

Synthesis . C 4 N 3 OH 7 ·ZnHPO 3 . A 7.45 g (50 mmol) amount of creatine hydrate (Osmo Chemicals), 0.81 g (10 mmol) of ZnO (St Joseph's), 2.54 g (30 mmol) of H3PO3 (Alfa), and 18 g (1 mol) of H2O were shaken in a HDPE bottle and placed in a 70 °C oven for 24 h. Product recovery by vacuum filtration resulted in a crusty mass of 1.32 g (yield based on Zn = 51%) of transparent needles and prisms (to 0.5 mm). The pH of the mother liquors was 5. C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 has also been prepared from creatinine in place of creatine hydrate, but the crystal quality is worse.

Product recovery by vacuum filtration resulted in a crusty mass of 1.32 g (yield based on Zn = 51%) of transparent needles and prisms (to 0.5 mm). The pH of the mother liquors was 5. elements.content: Characterization . X-ray powder patterns (Bruker D8 diffractometer, Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.541 78 Å, T = 25 °C) for a ground portion of each sample were in good agreement with simulations on the basis of the appropriate single-crystal structure (see below) indicating phase purity and high crystallinity in each case. 31P and 13C MAS NMR data were collected on a Varian UNITY Inova spectrometer equipped with a Doty Scientific MAS probe and referenced to standards of 85% H3PO4 and (CH3)4Si, respectively.

elements.content: Crystal Structure Determinations . Suitable crystals (for C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3, block, ∼0.38 × 0.17 × 0.11 mm; for C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3, triangular plate, ∼0.31 × 0.23 × 0.05 mm; for (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O, faceted chunk, ∼0.15 × 0.14 × 0.08 mm) of each compound were mounted on thin glass fibers with cyanoacrylate adhesive. Intensity data for each phase were collected on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.710 73 Å, T = 20 ± 2 °C) with the aid of the SMART and SAINT software packages. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS with resulting correction factor ranges of 0.669−0.928 for C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 [7546 reflections scanned, 5731 unique (R Int = 0.015), 4775 with I > 2σ(I)], 0.858−0.928 for C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3 [6722 reflections scanned, 2771 unique (R Int = 0.035), 2023 with I > 2σ(I)], and 0.798−0.948 for (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O [11524 reflections scanned, 6924 unique (R Int = 0.035), 4342 with I > 2σ(I)].

elements.content: The starting positional parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms were located by direct methods in space groups P1̄ (No. 2) for C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 and (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O and P21/c (No. 14) for C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3, which were assumed for the remainder of the crystallographic studies. After isotropic refinement, most of the hydrogen atom positions for each phase could be discerned in difference Fourier maps. The phosphite P−H (d = 1.32 Å) and creatinine C−H and N−H atoms were relocated at idealized positions and refined by riding on their parent atoms. For C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3, the water-molecule H atoms were refined by riding in their as-found positions. For (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O, the water-molecule H atoms were not located. The final difference maps were satisfactory (C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3:  min/max Δρ = −0.62/+0.48 e Å-3; C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3:  min/max Δρ = −0.43/+0.58 e Å-3; (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O:  min/max Δρ = −0.34/+0.63 e Å-3). All calculations were performed with SHELXL-97; details are summarized in Table .

Both of the tetrahedrally coordinated zinc atoms are surrounded by three O atoms (also bonded to P) and one N atom, the latter being the imidazole-like nitrogen atom of a creatinine molecule (see Chart 1). Because this molecule is directly bonded to Zn by formal donation of its electron lone pair (i.e., a Lewis base), it could be described as a ligand rather than a template. The average Zn−O bond length of 1.929(2) Å is distinctly shorter than the average Zn−N bond length of 2.037(2) Å. Each P atom makes three O atom bridges [d av(P−O) = 1.512 (2) Å] to Zn near neighbors and bonds to one H atom, thus showing normal behavior for phosphorus(III). The six framework O atoms form Zn−O−P bridges, with θav = 144.9°. The geometrical parameters for creatinine show no unexpected features and both asymmetric molecules are essentially planar [non-hydrogen atom root-mean-square (rms) deviation from the best least-squares plane = 0.019 for the N1 molecule and 0.020 for the N4 molecule]. The refinement makes clear that the terminal nitrogen atoms (N3 and N6) are doubly protonated; thus, overall, these ligands are neutral, in accordance with the charge-balancing requirement.

elements.content: The ZnO3N and HPO3 building blocks in C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 combine to generate a structure with strong two-dimensional character containing infinite tetrahedral sheets (Figure ) built up from 4-ring and 8-ring loops (i.e., four or eight polyhedral centers, respectively). The minimum and maximum atom-to-atom dimensions of the squashed 8-ring are 5.36 Å (O2···O2) and 9.18 Å (O5···O5), respectively. The ZnO3N and HPO3 moieties strictly alternate and the layers propagate in the (100) plane. The pendant creatinine groups project away from the sheets, and intersheet bonding (Figure ) involves an interleaving motif of these groupings. The P−H bonds also project away from the layers.

The minimum and maximum atom-to-atom dimensions of the squashed 8-ring are 5.36 Å (O2⋅⋅⋅O2) and 9.18 Å (O5⋅⋅⋅O5), respectively. The ZnO3N and HPO3 moieties strictly alternate and the layers propagate in the (100) plane. The pendant creatinine groups project away from the sheets, and intersheet bonding (Figure ) involves an interleaving motif of these groupings. The P-H bonds also project away from the layers.

elements.content: Hydrogen bonding is significant in stabilizing this structure. Both the NH2 moieties make two N−H···O bonds (Figure , Table ):  one to an acceptor phosphite O atom in the same sheet; one to an acceptor OC group in an adjacent creatinine molecule but also part of the same sheet. There are no hydrogen bonding interactions involving the P−H bond, which is expected, as this H atom does not show acidic behavior. There are no intersheet hydrogen bonds in this phase.

The tetrahedral zinc atom is surrounded by three O atoms (one water molecule + two also bonded to P) and one N atom belonging to an essentially planar (rms deviation from the best least-squares plane = 0.032 Å) creatinine molecule. The P atom makes two O atom bridges to Zn near neighbors, one terminal P−O vertex and one P−H bond. The average Zn−O and P−O bond lengths are 1.926(3) and 1.510(3) Å, respectively, and the average bond angle of the two O atoms forming Zn−O−P bridges is 139.3°. Once again, the terminal nitrogen atom N3 of the creatinine species is doubly protonated.

elements.content: The building blocks in C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3 combine to yield a simple but novel cluster, consisting of a single 4-ring loop of alternating ZnO3N and HPO3 moieties. Inversion symmetry generates the complete cluster, which is neutral. The clusters stack in the [010] direction and are arranged to form pseudosheets in the (001) plane (Figure ). There are both intracluster and intercluster hydrogen bonds in this phase. The N3H2 moiety makes one intracluster N−H···O bond (Figure ) and one N−H···O link to a similar adjacent unit. The bound water molecule (O4) makes two intercluster Zn−O−H···O bonds. As before, the P−H bond does not participate in H bonding.

Both the tetrahedrally coordinated zinc atoms are surrounded by two O atoms (also bonded to P) and two creatinine N atoms [d av(Zn−O) = 1.954 (2) Å; d av(Zn−N) = 1.989 (2) Å]. The P atoms both make two O atom bridges to Zn near neighbors and also possess P−Ot (t = terminal) and P−H vertexes [d av(P−Ot) = 1.502 (2) Å; d av(P−OZn) = 1.525 (2) Å]. Of the six framework O atoms, four form Zn−O−P bridges (θav = 130.2°) and two are terminal to P. The geometrical parameters for the essentially planar (rms deviation from the best least-squares plane = 0.036, 0.017, 0.052, and 0.023 Å, for the N1-, N4-, N7-, and N11-containing molecules, respectively) creatinine species are normal, and once again, the terminal nitrogen atoms (N3, N6, N9, and N12) are doubly protonated. The dihedral angle between the planes described by the N1- and N4-containing molecules (both attached to Zn1) is 83.96(7)°; thus, to a first approximation they are perpendicular A similar value of 84.44(7)° arises for the N7 and N11 moieties attached to Zn2. All the NH2 moieties make two N−H···O bonds (Figure ), and it is notable that each of the four Zn−O−P chain oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O4, and O5) acts as an intrachain acceptor for such a bond.

elements.content: The ZnO2N2 and HPO3 building blocks in C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 combine to generate a novel structure with strong one-dimensional character containing single, corrugated, chains (Figure ) of alternating zinc- and phosphorus-centered tetrahedra, propagating in the [010] direction. Overall, the structure also has pseudolayered character, with sheets of chains propagating in the (011) plane (Figure ) and intersheet connectivity established by H bonds and van der Waals forces.

elements.content: NMR Data. The 13C and 31P spectra for the title compounds are shown in Figures and , respectively. The 13C spectra each show four well-separated resonances, of roughly equal intensity, some of which are broadened or split, at δ ≈ 183, 165, 55, and 31 ppm (relative to a standard of Me4Si). These must correspond to the four chemically distinct carbon atoms in the creatinine moieties. On the basis of simple chemical shift calculations, we attribute these four signals to the carbonyl (e.g. C1 or C5 in Figure ), guanidinium-like (C4 or C8), methylene (C2 or C6), and terminal methyl (C3 or C7) carbon atoms, respectively. The calculated chemical shifts are 190, 120−160 (uncertain), 56.2, and 30.4 ppm, respectively. The corresponding solution-phase (solvent D2O) 13C chemical shifts of creatinine are 191.5, 171.8, 58.9, and 32.7 ppm, respectively.

The doublets and broad peaks seen in Figure may represent partial resolution of these signals due to multiple crystallographic environments, although the broadening may also arise from 13C−15N coupling. We note that the terminal methyl and carbonyl signals for C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3 are very sharp, as expected for a material containing crystallographically unique species.

elements.content: The 31P spectra, all occurring close to δ = 0 ppm (referenced to 85% H3PO4), show two lines of essentially equal intensity for C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3, one line for C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3 and one line for (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O. The two line spectrum for C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 presumably corresponds to the two P atom sites, although, because they are so chemically similar, it is hard to guess which resonance corresponds to which P atom. C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3 has a single distinct P atom; thus, one line is expected. On the basis of its structure, we would expect two lines for the (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O spectrum, but presumably, they overlap. Making this assumption, the 31P NMR data are all consistent with the crystal structures reported above.

elements.content: Three new creatinine zinc phosphites, C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3, C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3, and (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O, have been prepared by typical solution-phase reactions and structurally characterized. As is typical for hydrothermally prepared networks, three completely different structures have arisen from the same starting materials. In all cases, the creatine starting material is transformed to creatinine before formation of the crystalline product. It is not yet clear whether the this transformation plays a key role in directing the synthesis of these products, or whether, as for C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3, both creatine and creatinine can result in the same product.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Three new creatinine zinc phosphites, C4N3OH7⋅ZnHPO3, C4N3OH7⋅Zn(H2O)HPO3, and (C4N3OH7)2⋅ZnHPO3⋅H2O, have been prepared by typical solution-phase reactions and structurally characterized. As is typical for hydrothermally prepared networks, three completely different structures have arisen from the same starting materials. In all cases, the creatine starting material is transformed to creatinine before formation of the crystalline product. It is not yet clear whether the this transformation plays a key role in directing the synthesis of these products, or whether, as for C4N3OH7⋅ZnHPO3, both creatine and creatinine can result in the same product.

elements.content: A notable feature of these three materials is the different degree of ligation by the organic species and water at the zinc centers. If all four vertexes of the Zn-centered tetrahedron make Zn−O−P links, and the phosphite groups make three P−O−Zn bonds, then the resulting structures can be topologically regarded as (4,3)-connected nets. Here, the occurrence of Zn−N and Zn−OH2 bonds prevent the formation of a full complement of Zn−O−P links. Thus, C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 has one “blocked” Zn vertex (a Zn−N link) and C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3 and (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O have two blocked vertexes (as Zn−N + Zn−OH2 and two Zn−N bonds, respectively). The presence of direct Zn−N(ligand) bonds is uncommon, but not unprecedented, in organically templated zincophosphate structures. For example, the recently reported phase (C3N2H4)3·Zn4P3O11(OH) contains both ZnO3N and ZnO2N2 tetrahedra in its layered structure. Zn−OH2 links have also been seen in zincophosphates. A neutral template/ligand, as found here, is very unusual for zincophosphates, with (C3N2H4)3·Zn4P3O11(OH) the only known example, but has already been seen in other zincophosphites such as α-ZnHPO3·C2N4H4 12 and [H2N(CH2)2NH2]0.5·ZnHPO3.

Here, the occurrence of Zn-N and Zn-OH2 bonds prevent the formation of a full complement of Zn-O-P links. Thus, C4N3OH7⋅ZnHPO3 has one "blocked" Zn vertex (a Zn-N link) and C4N3OH7⋅Zn(H2O)HPO3 and (C4N3OH7)2⋅ZnHPO3⋅H2O have two blocked vertexes (as Zn-N + Zn-OH2 and two Zn-N bonds, respectively). The presence of direct Zn-N(ligand) bonds is uncommon, but not unprecedented, in organically templated zincophosphate structures. For example, the recently reported phase (C3N2H4)3⋅Zn4P3O11(OH) contains both ZnO3N and ZnO2N2 tetrahedra in its layered structure. Zn-OH2 links have also been seen in zincophosphates. A neutral template/ligand, as found here, is very unusual for zincophosphates, with (C3N2H4)3⋅Zn4P3O11(OH) the only known example, but has already been seen in other zincophosphites such as α-ZnHPO3⋅C2N4H4 12 and [H2N(CH2)2NH2]0.5⋅ZnHPO3.

elements.content: In terms of tetrahedral connectivity, the simple, zero-dimensional cluster in C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO3 and the simple chain in (C4N3OH7)2·ZnHPO3·H2O are novel. A similar 4-ring-based cluster has been seen for zincophosphates7,9 but with the addition of pendant dihydrogen phosphate moieties attached to Zn and an overall negative charge. Very recently, we have also reported a neutral, molecular, creatinine zinc phosphate, C4N3OH7·Zn(H2O)HPO4, although its crystal symmetry is different from that of the phosphite described here. The 4.82 sheets in C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 represent a recurring motif in zincophosphite chemistry:  similar layers have been seen in α-ZnHPO3·C2N4H4 12 and [H2N(CH2)2NH2]0.5·ZnHPO3, although the degree of sheet puckering and 8-ring window squashing varies widely for the inorganic sheet in these phases.
elements.clean_text: In terms of tetrahedral connectivity, the simple, zero-dimensional cluster in C4N3OH7⋅Zn(H2O)HPO3 and the simple chain in (C4N3OH7)2⋅ZnHPO3⋅H2O are novel. A similar 4-ring-based cluster has been seen for zincophosphates7,9 but with the addition of pendant dihydrogen phosphate moieties attached to Zn and an overall negative charge. Very recently, we have also reported a neutral, molecular, creatinine zinc phosphate, C4N3OH7⋅Zn(H2O)HPO4, although its crystal symmetry is different from that of the phosphite described here. The 4.82 sheets in C4N3OH7⋅ZnHPO3 represent a recurring motif in zincophosphite chemistry: similar layers have been seen in α-ZnHPO3⋅C2N4H4 12 and [H2N(CH2)2NH2]0.5⋅ZnHPO3, although the degree of sheet puckering and 8-ring window squashing varies widely for the inorganic sheet in these phases.

elements.content: The combination of subtle effects that generate the overall structure in these types of phases are well exemplified by the case of C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3. Figure shows that three types of weak, secondary (compared to strong, well-defined covalent bonds) bonding interaction define the way that the 4.82 sheets stack:  N−H···O hydrogen bonding between adjacent, pendant organic groups occurs in the [011] direction, pseudo-π−π stacking between creatinine rings in the [011̄] direction, and van der Waals' forces in the [100] (sheet stacking) direction. Rationalizing the interplay of such subtle and relatively weak chemical forces represents a major challenge in terms of predicting and understanding these types of materials.

Rationalizing the interplay of such subtle and relatively weak chemical forces represents a major challenge in terms of predicting and understanding these types of materials.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis . C 4 N 3 OH 7 ·ZnHPO 3 . A 7.45 g (50 mmol) amount of creatine hydrate (Osmo Chemicals), 0.81 g (10 mmol) of ZnO (St Joseph's), 2.54 g (30 mmol) of H3PO3 (Alfa), and 18 g (1 mol) of H2O were shaken in a HDPE bottle and placed in a 70 °C oven for 24 h. Product recovery by vacuum filtration resulted in a crusty mass of 1.32 g (yield based on Zn = 51%) of transparent needles and prisms (to 0.5 mm). The pH of the mother liquors was 5. C4N3OH7·ZnHPO3 has also been prepared from creatinine in place of creatine hydrate, but the crystal quality is worse.

C 4 N 3 OH 7 ·Zn(H 2 O)HPO 3 . A 5.96 g (40 mmol) amount of creatine hydrate, 0.81 g (10 mmol) of ZnO, 3.38 g (40 mmol) of H3PO3, and 18 g of H2O were reacted as above. Product recovery resulted in 1.69 g (yield = 61%) of small, transparent, prismatic blocks (pH of the mother liquors = 4).

(C 4 N 3 OH 7 ) 2 ·ZnHPO 3 ·H 2 O . A 8.94 g (60 mmol) amount of creatine hydrate, 0.81 g (10 mmol) of ZnO, 1.69 g (20 mmol) of H3PO3, and 18 g of H2O were reacted as above. Product recovery resulted in 2.84 g (yield = 76%) of transparent platy crystals (pH of the mother liquors = 6).
